admreg: Europe and Central Asia,Europe and Central Asia
trustfund: TF036514-GEORGIA - POWER REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF036041-GEORGIA - POWER REHABILITATION,TF035958-GEORGIA - POWER PRIVATIZATION,TF033206-GEORGIA - POWER REHABILITATION PROJECT,TF032450-GEORGIA - POWER

abstracts.cdata!:
The outcome of the Power Rehabilitation
            Project is rated as satisfactory, sustainability as likely,
            institutional development impact as substantial, bank
            performance as satisfactory, borrower performance as
            unsatisfactory. The most important lesson learned from the
            project is that profitable, efficient commercial operation
            of energy enterprises in Georgia is difficult to achieve
            under public management. The recovery of the sector requires
            involvement of private strategic investors with sufficient
            clout to resist the political pressure and vested interest,
            and whose commercial interests are derived from a sustained
            and efficient operation of the companies rather than
            short-term political and commercial deals. Investment
            projects have to be accompanied by institutional and policy
            reforms needed to sustain project benefits. Actions on both
            fronts are needed as they are mutually re-enforcing.
            Coordination with other donors provided significant leverage
            and synergies, both within the project and through the
            associated Bank's operations. Ownership of the project,
            as well as of the accompanying reforms, is critical. At the
            project level, intensive technical assistance to the
            implementing agency in procurement, financial management,
            contract administration, and project management, and close
            supervision of the project have been very important.
